You can revisit the tale and develop it later, or leave it as it is.In telling the story, donrsquot think of words, think of the images created in your head, then the words will come naturally as you describe what you see.This way you will remember the story. You may tell it slightly dferently each time, but thatrsquos fine. Your child may remind you of how it was told before, as he or she will have their own visualisation of the tale.Or your child may ask you for a dferent story, in which case you are back at the base of another story mountain ready to climb it!Happy storytelling!

title: plans-for-250-more-homes-in-dunbar-to-be-revealed
story: Members of the public have the chance to view the proposals on Tuesday, with the developers hoping to submit a planning application with East Lothian Council in the spring.The site, between the East Coast Mainline, Beveridge Row and the Lochend Campus of the townrsquos primary school, was earmarked for development in East Lothian Councilrsquos Local Development Plan .Currently, the plans are still at an early stage, with approximately  houses earmarked for the .-hectare site.The proposed development, known as Hallhill North, would also include an area designated for a recreation sports pitch for community use in close proximity to the primary school.Options for renewable energy provision are being considered for the site.The LDP notes: ldquoAny development here is subject to the mitigation of any development related impacts, including on a proportionate basis for any cumulative impacts with other proposals including on the transport network and on education and community facilities as appropriate.Ahead of a public exhibition, which will be held at the townrsquos Hallhill Sports Centre from pm to .pm on Tuesday, Ken Ross, from Hallhill Developments Ltd, noted the impact the Hallhill development had made in the last  years.Economist Tony Mackay produced an economic impact assessment in  which concluded that existing and future Hallhill developments will contribute nearly pound million annually to the East Lothian economy and will generate more than  jobs.Mr Ross said: ldquoHallhill North will not only involve much-needed housing, including affordable housing, but will also include provision for a sports pitch for community use.Jacquie Bell, Dunbar Community Council secretary, said: ldquoThere is not much we can do about the go-ahead outline, I think what we can try to influence is the detail of what they put in.Mrs Bell was keen for social housing and bungalows to be included within the development.She noted concerns had also been expressed about how the townrsquos infrastructure, such as medical centre and primary school, would cope with further expansion, as well as fears it would lead to wildle, such as deer, being displaced and even killed on neighbouring roads.More detailed plans for the site are expected to be revealed at the consultation event.Ward councillor Norman Hampshire said ldquoone or two issues still needed to be dealt with, including the potential road layout, as well as financial contributions to schools.

title: public-thanked-for-huge-support-for-east-lothian-foodbank
story: Customers at the countyrsquos Tesco stores did their bit to help the East Lothian Foodbank during a three-day collection late last year.Once again, it proved a great success, with the Tranent-based charity collecting , kilogrammes of non-perishable food over the three days, compared to , kilogramme in .The foodbank was helped at the three stores by the newly-acclaimed volunteer team of the year award winners, volunteers of East Lothian Foodbank and by ious Rotary clubs in the county, from Dunbar, Haddington, Tranent and Musselburgh, as well as Inner Wheel and Police Scotlandrsquos youth volunteers.Peter Dicker, East Lothian Foodbank manager, said: ldquoOnce again we have been astounded by the generosity of people in East Lothian with the total collected at the Tesco stores.ldquoAs well as people giving us the food, we must make a special mention of the people who voluntarily give their time to help us with the collection.ldquoAn extra special mention must go to Iain Hastie and his team at Wood Pellets East Lothian for driving round the three stores and collecting all the donations and delivering them to the foodbank in Tranent.ldquoWe would also like to thank Martin Whitfield MP and Iain Gray MSP for their continued support at Musselburgh and Haddington helping with the collections.ldquoWe must also thank the people and organisations who continue to deliver donations to us so generously.Meanwhile, the charity has also benefited from generous visitors to enjoyleisurersquos sports facilities across the county.enjoyleisure ran a lsquoRemember, Remember the Foodbank this Novemberrsquo campaign.In total, the donations collected across enjoyleisurersquos six sports centres amounted to kg, which equates to about  meals.Bill Axon, enjoyleisure general manager, said: ldquoAs a community organisation, we wanted to show our support to this invaluable local initiative and assist those who are in need of its services.ldquoWe are incredibly grateful to our customers and staff who contributed donations. Their generosity will help lighten the load for others this festive season.

title: increase-in-number-of-scots-struggling-to-pay-mortgage-and-rent-costs
story: Research by YouGov, on behalf of Shelter Scotland, indicated that % ofa sample size of  people said they were currently struggling to pay their rent or mortgage costs.The figure is an increase on the % of respondents from two years ago when the same survey was conducted.YouGov suggest that the % figure is equivalent to nearly , households in Scotland.As many as four in respondents said that they would struggle to pay their rent or mortgageit rose by as little as pound a month during , while % admitted they had at least once borrowed money from a friend, used a credit card or used their savings to pay their rent or mortgage.Shelter Scotland has warned that ignoring money worries rather than seeking advice could lead to peoplersquos homes being put at risk.According to the charity, one household every  minutes was made homeless in Scotland last year, with nearly , households forced to live in temporary accommodation ndash including more than , children.Graeme Brown, director of Shelter Scotland, said: ldquoItrsquos quite clear from these numbers that tens of thousands of people in Scotland are entering  worrying about meeting the costs of their rent or mortgage over the next few months and that many thousands more would struggle with even a modest rise on those costs.ldquoA perfect storm of austerity, harsh welfare reforms, stagnant wages, job insecurity and the high cost of housing are making it harder for people to make ends meet and plan for the future.ldquoItrsquos a disgrace that in st century Scotland so many people should have to worry about the basic right of keeping a roof over their heads.Mr Brown also said that Shelter advisers are available to help anyone worried about paying for their housing costs, at risk of homelessness or struggling with bad housing.ldquoItrsquos absolutely vital that people who do find themselves struggling to make ends meet and keep a roof over their heads should seek help sooner rather than later, he said.ldquoItrsquos much better to put a plan in place to deal with debt and arrears in the early stages rather than wait for eviction notices and court orders.ldquoAll year round our teams are ready to help, but, in order to do so, we need help from the public so we can keep up our fight against bad housing and homelessness.

title: more-than-700-safety-events-recorded-at-nuclear-bases
story: Defence Minister Stuart Andrew revealed the figures in letters to SNP MP Deidre Brock.A total of  nuclear safety events were recorded at HM Naval Base Clyde at Faslane and nearby Royal Naval Armaments Depot Coulport in the  years between  and .Earlier the MoD disclosed  incidents had taken place at Faslane, where the majority of the UKrsquos nuclear submarine fleet is based.Now, a further letter shows  incidents took place at Coulport, where the nuclear warheads are stored and loaded onto the submarines, in the same period.In the letter, Mr Andrew said: ldquoI would wish to reiterate that the identication and reporting of these low-level events and near misses is actively encouraged in line with International Atomic Energy Agency guidance for protecting people and the environmenthellip since such data can provide valuable lessons to help avoid more signicant events.A Category A incident took place in  when water overflowed from a now-decommissioned primary effluent barge.Category A events have ldquoactual or high potential for radioactive release to the environment of quantities in excess of IRR notication limits.Subsequent sampling indicated low levels of Tritium and ldquobarely detectable levels of cobalt.The incident was reported to the Defence Nuclear Safety Regulator and the Scottish Environmental Protection Agency and the assessed release to the Gare Loch was less on .% of the basersquos approved annual discharge levels.Earlier, the MoD listed two Category A incidents at Faslane, from  and .However, the minister said that in ldquoneither event was any radiological contamination evident.He continued: ldquoNone of the events caused harm to the health of any member of staff on the Naval Base, or to any member of the public.Mr Andrew said that the MoD takes all incidents, no matter how minor, ldquoextremely seriously and that they are investigated with appropriate measures put in place.In response to parliamentary questions from Ms Brock, the MoD also disclosed there have been  fires on its nuclear armed or nuclear powered submarines since June .ldquoItrsquos a shocking record of accidents and incidents in places where the most dangerous weapons on the planet are, Ms Brock said.ldquoWe already knew that there were  nuclear safety events on board submarines while they were berthed at Faslane and now we find that there have been another  in other locations at Faslane and at Coulport where weapons are handled.She added: ldquoOne bad accident would be enough to wipe Scotland out and the safety record is appalling.ldquoEven the risks from the nuclear reactors on board submarines is too high ndash as the spillage from the effluent barge shows.

title: university-partnership-to-help-armed-forces-veterans
story: Glasgow Caledonian University , Edinburgh Napier Universityand Veterans Scotland will jointly host an event on Tuesday in Glasgow to exhibit how universities and colleges can support ex-military personnel and their families.In Scotland, there are around , veterans of dferent ages, social backgrounds andof service.GCU and ENU are both signed up to the Armed Forces Covenant, a promise from the nation that those who serve or have served in the military and their families are treated fairly.The event forms part of theGCU-HM Forces Learning Partnership,designed specically for military personnel looking to advance their career or change direction.Jim Castle, GCUrsquos Veterans and Armed Forces champion, said that many of the skills learned by veterans during their time in service can be transferred across dferent industries.ldquoAll servicemen and women have been trained in battlefield evacuation, said Mr Castle.ldquoThey learn how to treat someone who has been badly injured, to keep them alive until medics arrive and airlt them to the nearest hospital base.ldquoThis is called lsquothe golden hourrsquo, and the theory is thatyou can keep someone alive for an hour they will survive. This is a massive skill and they all have it.ldquoThey also have physical fitness, leadership skills, decision making, commitment, respect for others, teamwork, loyalty, integrity, discipline and courage to name just a few.ldquoIn a nutshell, they have a huge range of transferable skills, which combined with education, will maximise their potential and make them highly employable and major assets to society and the economy.Speakers at the event include GCU principal and vice-chancellor Professor Pamela Gillies, MSPs Annie Wells and Maurice Corry, Scottish Veterans Commissioner Colonel Charlie Wallace and Deputy Commander of  Infantry Brigade and HQ Scotland Colonel Sandy Fitzpatrick.Professor Nolan, principal and vice-chancellor of ENU, said: ldquoFormer armed forces personnel have so much to offer in terms of skills and le experience.ldquoAs a university, we are committed to supporting their transition to civilian le and future career development through mentoring programmes for veterans who work with us and flexible entry paths on to degree courses for prospective students.Scottish Conservative MSP Annie Wells said it was ldquofantastic that GCU was taking the joint lead in supporting Scotlandrsquos veterans reach their full potential after leaving the military.Ms Well said: ldquoAll too often we hear of cases of those in the military who have been let down upon their attempts to integrate back into civilian le. Initiatives such as this will go a long way in ensuring positive outcomes for those who have served our country so well.Former Scots Guardsman John Templeton, who is now a registered mental health nurse after graduating from GCU in November, said that being part of the support network at GCU had changed his le.He said: ldquoI think the GCU-HM Forces Learning Partnership does a great job. We need to shout it from the rooftops and let people know about it.

title: highlands-and-islands-given-tourism-projects-funding-boost
story: The pound million Natural and Cultural Heritage Fund, led by Scottish Natural Heritage , will open for applications on Monday aimed at boosting projects seeking to benefit the area, including improving the experience of visitors.The funding comes through the Scottish Governmentrsquos European Regional Development Fund programme, with match funding from other sources, bringing overall investment to more than pound million.The fund will invest in around  major new projects and, in addition to promoting nature and culture, will seek to create and support jobs in the area.Job creation is cited as a key measure of success for the fund, with projects encouraged to demonstrate benefits such as creating and sustaining employment, businesses and services in the local community.Applications can be submitted from the public, voluntary or third sectors.The fund is not suitable for applications from the private sector, iniduals, commercial enterprise or organisations run entirely by volunteers.Fiona Hyslop, Cabinet Secretary for Culture, Tourism and External Affairs, said: ldquoTourism is an important aspect of the Highlands and Islands economy, with many communities dependent on visitors who are attracted to the region by its beautul landscapes, wildle, heritage and culture.ldquoI am pleased to see Scottish Natural Heritage launch this fund and encourage relevant applicants from the area to come forward and apply.ldquoThe Natural and Cultural Heritage Fund will target resources accordingly to more remote and rural parts of the region, supporting much-needed jobs and bringing additional economic and social benefits.SNH chief executive Francesca Osowska said: ldquoThis new fund presents fantastic opportunities to show how investing in the environment and culture of the Highlands and Islands can bring signicant economic benefits for rural communities.ldquoSNH has already met with over  prospective applicants at events across the mutedcontrolsHe simply did what marked him out since his junior days, dedicated his le to wringing every last drop out of his talent.Murray had the perfect motivation as a child growing up in Dunblane ndash wanting to beat his brother Jamie, who is only  months older ndash and his competitive spirit did not always make for a happy household.Scotland is still very much home evenhe has not lived there permanently for more than half his le, and it is a source of immense pride that to many Dunblane is now known as the birthplace of champions rather than for the tragedy that claimed the lives of  of the Murray brothersrsquo fellow primary school pupils.Murray played many dferent sports as a child, excelling at football ndash his maternal grandfather was a professional player ndash and tennis, where being on court allowed him to spend time with his mother Judy, who was forging a successful career as a tennis coach.By his early teens, Murray had established himself as one of the best young players in Europe, and a conversation with rival Nadal, who could count on former world number one Carlos Moya as a practice partner, led the Scot to broaden his horizons.Murray headed off to train in Barcelona before making his first big mark on the global stage by winning the US Open junior title at the age of .Shy, unkempt and with no desire to be a celebrity, Murray on the court stood out for the iety in his game, his tennis brain, his speed and, most of all, his tenacity.Murray matches were not always pretty, although he could be spectacular as well as dogged, but he will be remembered most of all for his sheer determination to find a way to win.If there was a criticism, it was that Murray seemed to have too many options and his default setting was to rely on his remarkable defensive and physical abilities. Would he still be playinghe had not put his body through quite so much punishment Ivan Lendl, under whom Murray won all his biggest inidual titles, was the only coach able to consistently ramp up his chargersquos aggression, while tempering the Scotrsquos tendency to allow negativity to overwhelm him.It was no surprise Murray struggled to keep believing when always standing in his way were three of the all-time greats. Four times he lost in slam finals, twice to Djokovic and twice to Federer, before finally breaking his duck in appropriately gruelling fashion against Djokovic at the US Open in .The following summer came his career-defining moment when he ended Britainrsquos -year wait for a male singles champion at Wimbledon, adding a second title three years later then writing his own piece of history by becoming the first tennis player to win back-to-back Olympic gold medals in singles.In the autumn of , with his rivals at last showing some weakness, Murray surged thrillingly to the top of the rankings, clinching the number one spot by winning the ATP Finals in London.What seemed like it might be the start of the Murray era turned out instead to be a glorious swansong. Barely six months later, the first signs of his hip problem emerged and, despite surgery and an extensive rehabilitation and reconditioning programme, there has been no way back to the top.Perhaps even more important than his achievements on the court, the understated Murray emerged as one of the sportrsquos great trend-setters.First there was Murrayrsquos realisation in his early twenties that, rather than just employing a coach, having a team of people around him would help him reach his peak physically and mentally.Then, with a grand slam title still tantalisingly elusive, he reached out to a former great in Lendl, establishing the trend of the super coach. When their partnership came to an end, Murray broke more ground by hiring Amelie Mauresmo, who became the most high-profile female coach in tennis.Most top sportsmen would rather not stick their head above the parapet but, once he became comfortable in the limelight, Murray swam against the tide, speaking out forcefully on issues like equality and doping.He also embraced his role as the figurehead of British tennis, actively supporting and encouraging those emerging in his wake. They could not have bigger shoes to fill.

title: joanna-blythman-reviews-dhoom-in-dunfermline
story: I have always admired the work of the architect responsible, Richard Murphy, although seeing is believing. This extension is made up of several spaces that gradually unfold, rewarding inquisitiveness. Its internal views are ied and intriguing, leading you on from one set of interesting artefacts to another. At the back it sits unassumingly across the graveyard looking over to the medieval, Romanesque Dunfermline Abbey, adding up to fitting, fluid juxtaposition of old and new. Consequently, we spend much longer here than intended, wersquore hungry, and although the gallery cafeacute looks better than most, wersquove spotted a big, bright, new Indian restaurant Dhoom, which boasts ldquotapas styled food from slender streets of India. This promise we have to test.Dhoom is a big, ambitious place. Tables inside tuk-tuks, swing seats, tin chairs, corrugated metal table table iders, faux junkyard wood, steel cups, and looped garlands of light bulbs that conjure up a roadside night market, its determined to tick all the decorative boxes that currently flag up cool Indian sharing food.So itrsquos bliss to dip a spoon in the Rajasthani goat curry, a fabulous bargainat pound. for what almost amounts to a main course portion. This shows us that Doom can spice with skill not just fry: tender meat, an earthy, almost masculine spice blend- peppercorns, black cardamom, maybe - that heats the back of the throat delivering the effect of an expectorant drug. Goan fish curry is, by contrast, sweet , mild, emollient,rather simple. The sauce, save its decorative fried fresh curry leaves, doesnrsquot amount to much more than mango pulp added to coconut milk. The fish itself is vapid, therersquos nothing to hint at its species, itrsquos just anonymously white. The paratha is good.Dessert-wise Dhoom isnrsquot up and running. Its kulfis arenrsquot made on the premises, wersquore told. We decline the ldquowhite chocolate samosa, probably deep-fried, and settle instead for reasonable home-made gulab jamun, dumplings, which, of course, are once again fried, immersed in sweet syrup and here, squirted with redundant sweet chocolate sauce. Dhoom coaxes and caresses the deep-fried, sugary cravings of the Scots. Itrsquoll probably go down a treat.Dhoom, - New Row, Dunfermline  Food rating:  Atmosphere:  Value for money:  Service:

title: doctors-ban-misleading-health-messages-from-food-packaging-to-curb-obesity
story: Medical leaders from BMA Scotland also called on the Government to consider introducing mandatory reformulation of food products high in sugar, fat and salt and to ensure that restrictions on marketing junk food apply online as well as in shops and supermarkets.The trade union was responding to the Scottish Governments consultation on its obesity strategy. A Healthier Future, which closes on January .The plans could see Scotland become the first country in the world to pass legislation banning multi-buy promotions on unhealthy foods as part of efforts to tackle obesity. Proposals also include capping portion sizes in restaurants and takeaways, mandatory calorie information on menus and extending the sugar tax to milky drinks like milkshakes and hot chocolates which contain less than % milk.In its response to the consultation, BMA Scotland said restrictions on price promotions "should be comprehensive and not allow exceptions", for example cracking down on buy-one-get-one-free deals but failing to target items such as multipacks of crisps and confectionary which are "designed to promote greater consumption".It added: "Consideration should also be given to banning the use of packaging to promote a productrsquos lsquohealthierrsquo nutritional content when one unhealthy nutrient has simply been replaced by another. For example it is not uncommon for products to prominently claim to be reduced or low fat when in reality this has been achieved by signicantly increasing a productrsquos sugar content. This risks misleading consumers who are trying to take a healthier approach to their purchases."It comes after retail and food industry representatives criticised the proposals as "badly thought through and unenforceable.The Food and Drink Federation Scotland said there was "no evidence of the effectiveness of these measures in tackling obesity", and stressed that the "promotion to adults of all foods is a fundamental commercial freedom".It added that one of its members - an unnamed ldquoiconic Scottish brand - could lose pound million in sales as a direct result of such measures, which it said would ldquolikely result in major redundancies.Ewan MacDonald-Russell, head of policy at the Scottish Retail Consortium said there was a "dearth of detail over the exact definition of products, categories, and store areas" and argued that there was no evidence to show that price promotions "encourage over-consumption".Dr Lewis Morrison, chair of BMA Scotland, said obesity was placing a "massive burden" on the NHS and "bold" action was needed.Dr Morrison said: ldquoSales promotions are routinely deployed by retailers to encourage consumers to purchase products and are disproportionately used to promote unhealthy food and drink. Their eye-catching nature also contributes to in-store environments that favour unhealthy dietary behaviour by drawing additional attention to such products.ldquoOn this basis it is clear that mandatory and comprehensive action is needed to help improve diets and reduce consumption of unhealthy products. Of course encouraging personal responsibility and education on how to eat healthily is also important, but it will not be enough unless bold, strong action on promotion and price is taken as well."

title: daily-mile-pioneer-elaine-wyllie-initiative-can-improve-everything-from-fitness-to-numeracy
story: At the time, Mrs Wyllie was the headteacher of St Ninians Primary in Stirling but that day she was covering the P class while their teacher attended a funeral.She had decided to take the pupils outside for a run after one of the schools local volunteers, an -year-old local landowner who helped out with music, storytelling and teaching the children chess, warned her out of the blue: "the children at this school are not fit"."I knew the children werent generally fit," said Mrs Wyllie, who retired in  after  years in teaching. "I asked the PE teacher Marion and she said theyre exhausted by the warm up in PE, most of them - most arent fit at all."So that afternoon I was covering a P class for a teacher who was at a funeral and I took them out for PE in the afternoon. I thought they can do their warm up running round the field and Ill see whos fit."Most of them, by the far end of the field, were exhausted - doubled up in pain with a stitch."Read more: Daily Mile does improve childrens fitness, major study findsIt was a watershed moment for the school. From that day on, the class went out for  minutes of running, jogging and walking each day to build up their speed and stamina.As the weeks went on, other classes and eventually the entire school joined in and the Daily Mile was born.What started le nearly seven years ago as one P class in a Stirling primary school trying to get active has given birth to a global phenomenon credited not only with improving fitness - butincreasingly also classroom concentration and attainment.Today the Daily Mile has been adopted by more than  primary and nursery schools worldwide, including nearly half in Scotland, and is a fixture as far afield as Australia and South Africa.Mrs Wyllie, , says the key to its success is its simplicity."There is something about the ownership, the motivation, the autonomy - and theres no failure. Everyone succeeds at their own Daily Mile. Theres no kit."Theissues around PE kit are eliminated: cool and not cool kit unwashed, missing, no kit. Theres no revealing of your body because youre not changing in front of people."Youre not running in skimpy shorts in front of people. And also, time spent changing is gone. The children just down tools and head straight outside."Its simple, its free and its sustainable. Its not one of these piecemeal initiatives that come and go."Read more: Childhood obesity rates would doublebody fat was measured instead of BMISince the Daily Mile first took hold, it has drawn attention from researchers - with some surprising findings. There are signs, for example, that it may be reversing a previously steady rise in dyspraxia rates.Dyspraxia is a developmental condition affecting physical coordination and motor skills, as well as memory and information processing. The cause is unknown, although active play has been shown to improve motor .Incidence has been increasing across the UK but researchers involved in a -year study, currently at the halfway point, were surprised when results from Scotland appeared to reveal the trend reversing.When they delved into it, the decline was being driven by schools participating in the Daily Mile.It comes after the results of a major study by the Universities of Edinburgh and Stirling, published in May, found that children who did the Daily Mile for seven months reduced their body fat and improved their fitness and overall activity levels.The benefits are not only physical, however. A study of maths performance among boys in a Morecambe Bay school is reporting an "acute improvement" in the numeracy of boys doing the Daily Mile.Read more: Attention span and memory improves after short burst of exercise, study findsThat concurs with the Coppermile report which followed  children at Coppermill Primary in London. Over  weeks in , the pupils ran, jogged or walked for  minutes at least three times a week.By the end of the study period, the average distance run was up %, but more striking was their academic performance.The Year  pupils were were sitting Englands SATs tests did the Daily Mile every day for a week prior to sitting the tests, which measure reading, writing, maths and grammar.The school had been predicted to achieve average results in the high s-low s. In reality, it scored between % in writing to % for maths and grammar - signicantly above the local and national average."Their attainment was up -% compared to the previous years results, and we know thats been replicated in Morecambe Bay," said Mrs Wylie. "Any headteacher would be happy with a % improvement."And whats more, when they did the measurements of those  childrens fitness at the beginning, % of the children had predicted poor health in later le based on their readings. That dropped to % after  weeks."The Daily Mile is not the only answer, but its a huge part of the answer and its a simple, free, impartial solution."

title: stuc-to-hold-summit-over-general-secretarys-outside-earnings
story: Grahame Smith made the offer last week after it was pointed out his counterpart south of the Border, Frances OrsquoGrady, would not benefit financiallyshe sat on public boards.The STUCrsquos governing general councillast year considered the ldquoadequacy of the processes for board appointments for members of its secretariat, which includes Smith, and members of the GC.A committee was asked to map the bodies the STUC is represented on, review procedures for agreeing and reporting outside positions, propose a process where invitations are cleared by the GC, and create a register of interest for senior STUC figures. The committee was also asked to review the remuneration packages received by figures including Smith and look at how the monies could best be recouped for the STUC.However, a paper drawn up for the committee flagged up dficulties with ideas such as recovering fees and requiring clearance for outside posts.The paper was expected to be considered at a meeting of the GC last week, but it is understood Smith proposed discussing the issues with office-bearers at a separate meeting. This was agreed.One insider said an important factor was the claim that OrsquoGrady, who leads the TUC, would not get paidshe sat on boards. The source believes reform in the STUC is now ldquoinevitable. The committee paper, leaked to this newspaper, irked supporters of reform as they believed it placed obstacles in the way of change.Regarding future procedures for the GC to clear invitations to serve on bodies, the paper sounded a cautious note: ldquoIf the general council wishes to introduce such conditions, including sanctions in relation to non-compliance, it will have to consider the contractual issues involved.The paper continued: ldquoThis will require an agreed or imposed iation to the current contractual arrangements between the general secretary secretariat and the STUC and will require to be reasonable and proportionate and consistent with fair work principles.On the issue of outside remuneration packages, the paper appeared to suggest any solution could be a long way off: ldquoUntil all the bodies on which the STUC is represented have been mapped, a register of interest established, the constitutional issues claried and iations to the current contractual arrangements between the general secretary secretariat and the STUC agreed or imposed, it will not be possible to determine existing remuneration packages. It added that, at present, outside remuneration is only available in relation to appointments over which the STUC GC has ldquono locus.

title: peter-ross-an-open-love-letter-to-andy-murray
story: Thank you. Thank you for all the great games, the bitten nails and the holy grails ndash those three grand slams, those two Olympic golds, that Davis Cup. Thanks for the dreams come true that we were so lucky to share.The day you won Wimbledon for the first time was one of the happiest of my le. It came after one of the saddest. My dad had died the summer before. He would have loved to have seen you win. I hope he did.I grew up watching tennis with my dad. We moved around a lot, but tennis on the telly was a constant. Stirling, Glasgow, Aberdeen, Alloa. Borg, McEnroe, Becker, Sampras, Federer. All those great champions and none of them British, much less Scottish. Then you came along. I remember your breakthrough at Wimbledon in . My dad phoned me, excited: ldquoWhorsquos this lad  He looks like he could do something.You certainly did.It got so I could mark out the major events of my adult le by how well or badly you were doing. When you were a teenager with potential, I was a new father, staying up late with the wee one to follow your matches in America and Australia.In , when you won the US Open and Olympics, I took my sons to see you parade through the streets of your home town. I wanted them to understand that this was history, that they were lucky to be growing up at a time when you were playing and winning. Fred Perry, for me, was a story in a book. Andy Murray, for them, was real. You were standing in front of them in Dunblane in the rain, a saltire around your shoulders, signing their tennis balls. The signatures might fade. Your achievement never will.The following year, when you won Wimbledon, I remember falling to my knees in tears I was so happy and relieved, but also upset that my dad hadnrsquot lived to see it. My boys did, though, and that is important to me.Thatrsquos the personal side, but you have been so important to the whole of Scotland. You have been a healing force, associating the name ldquoDunblane with something beautul. Also, for those of us who have lived with a feeling that Scotland is a nation of failure ndash sporting, political and otherwise ndash your success has been important psychologically and emotionally. You send a message: we can still do things. We have watched you grow up, and you helped us grow stronger.Let me tell you about that. I wrote on Twitter that you are a hero of mine. Folk wrote back to tell me they felt the same. They were crying at the news of your retirement. They had shared your joys and now shared your pain. The idea that you represent some sort of underdog spirit is not quite sufficient. People felt that they saw in your suffering something of their own, and in your victories a wee bit of hope. ldquoUnlike Federer, who just seemed to have it so easy, one woman wrote, "Andy was the guy for the peoplewho have things a bit shit who sometimes win, but very often lose.Is that what it is  Yoursquore a winner for losers  Maybe. Or a bit more complicated than that. What became clear, as you got older, was that yoursquore not just a great athlete, but a great person. You always seemed a bit wounded, injured at some deep level beyond the reach of physio and surgery. That might be to do with your childhood experience, your survival of the horror, or it might just be who you are. Either way, Id say it gives you empathy, means your emotions arenrsquot far below your skin. Your feminism and every other bit of decency for which yoursquove been praised stems, I feel, from that essential compassion. Maybe yoursquod have won moreyoursquod been tougher. Maybe yoursquod have lost something too.I felt terribly sorry for you at your press conference, as you announced that the Australian Open might be your last tournament. You want to play tennis. We want you to play tennis. But evenyou never serve another ball, yoursquove done enough. For us in Scotland this has been more than admiration for a sportsman. It has been something like love.Andy, we have never spoken, and you have no idea what you mean to me. But I hope you know what you mean to us.Peter Ross

title: no-deal-brexit-is-only-way-to-take-control-of-uk-borders-says-ex-tory-leader
story: Brexiteer Iain Duncan Smith said the UK would be able to start enjoying the benefits of Brexit from March  under a no-deal exit, rather than being left in ldquoBrexit in Name Only purgatory under the Prime Ministerrsquos deal.He described Theresa Mayrsquos withdrawal agreement ndash which is due to be voted on by MPs on Tuesday ndash as ldquoflawed, and instead proffered the benefits of leaving under World Trade Organisation terms.Mr Duncan Smith said: ldquoOnly by leaving the EU on WTO terms can the UK fully take back control of its borders and deal with these issues. In taking back control of our migration policy we are also giving notice to industry that we will have to invest and train to a far greater degree than they have for some time.ldquoThe greatest benefit of leaving under No Deal is that our country can start to enjoy the benefits of Brexit from March th , rather than being left in the BRINOpurgatory of Mrs Mayrsquos deal. The British people have already waited for almost three years ndash they should not have to wait any longer.His intervention came in a report published by Economists for Free Trade, in which fellow Tory Eurosceptic Jacob Rees-Mogg also said there was ldquonothing to fear from leaving the EU without a deal.Mr Rees-Mogg, the chairman of the European Research Group of Conservative MPs, claimed that while it would be better to leave with a deal, the advantages of Brexit would come through sooner without an agreement.He said: ldquoIn addition to goods continuing to flow, under a No-Deal departure, the British taxpayer would save pound billion, money which could be used to cut taxes, to help our domestic economy and leave plenty to help any exporters who face particularly high tarfs.ldquoThe advantages of Brexit would come through sooner with trade barriers going down in  instead of  which could see the cost of food, clothing and footwear fall sharplythe Government followed sensible policies. This particularly helps the least well off in society.Tory former Cabinet minister Owen Paterson, in the same report, suggested the ldquoreal reason for the ldquoEstablishment hysteria surrounding a no-deal exit ldquois that we actually would be leaving.ldquoThe other options now being floated ndash extending Article , a second referendum, or the subjugation demanded by the Withdrawal Agreement ndash are designed to hold the UK in the EUrsquos orbit in the hope that it may be sucked back in, he said.ldquoThese options would completely fail to honour the biggest democratic verdict ever delivered in British history, he said.ldquoThe optimal Brexit outcome remains a wide-ranging, zero-tarf free trade agreement as offered repeatedly by President Tusk. Such a deal can still be negotiated, but not by the end of March.ldquoHaving wasted so much time on the Withdrawal Agreement, leaving on WTO terms is now the only way to break free fully and build a more prosperous, independent future.

title: liam-fox-urged-to-clarify-uks-post-brexit-relationship-with-switzerland
story: SNP MP Angus MacNeil accused the International Trade Secretary of making "blithe assurances of progress" on the transition of a trade agreement between the two countries.Last month, the Government announced that it had approved an agreement with the Swiss Federal Council allowing businesses to continue trading freely after Brexit.The agreement replicates the existing EU-Switzerland arrangements "as far as possible" and will come into effect at the end of the implementation period in January  - or on March Britain crashes out of the EU without a deal.In a letter to Dr Fox, Mr MacNeil called for clarity on which aspects of the current relationship are replicated in the text and asked whether it would enable UK-based firms to continue trading into Switzerland on the "same basis as they do currently".Commenting on the letter to Dr Fox, Mr MacNeil said: "Switzerlands access to the single market requires it to accept both freedom of movement and a signicant proportion of EU law."It is based not only on a trade agreement eliminating tarfs but also on a myriad of other trade-related agreements. The Secretary of State must clary which aspects of this arrangement are replicated in this agreement with Switzerland."Has free movement been accepted as part of the agreement to roll-over  Does the agreement allow UK-based firms to continue trading into Switzerland on the same basis as they do today  And what about all the other  or so existing EU trade agreements "Blithe assurances of progress will simply not suffice as the clock ticks down to Brexit on March ."A Department for International Trade spokeswoman said: "The UK Government and the Swiss Federal Council have approved the transition of a trade agreement that replicates the existing EU-Switzerland arrangements as far as possible."This will allow businesses to continue trading freely after the UK leaves the European Union."

title: the-key-to-new-years-resolution-success-scrap-dry-january-and-give-up-giving-up
story: But according to experts, the key to success is to go with the flow, scrap Dry January and give up on giving up.Research conducted by a sports social network has revealed January th to be the day where motivation is at its lowest, and most people are likely to give up on their resolutions.Strava, a social network for athletes, analysed more than  million online global activities before pinpointing the day people are most likely to give up trying to stick to their goals.While some experts say writing goals down, focusing on one thing at a time or constantly reflecting on your progress is the key to success, Scots mindfulness expert Martin Stepek has suggested that re-phrasing negative resolutions may be what people are missing.Martin, who runs Hamilton-based firm Ten For Zen said gimmicks such as Veganuary and Dry January may do more harm than good when it comes to changing peoplersquos habits.He said: ldquoThe way we live our lives now, whether itrsquos healthy or unhealthy, is just a series of habits we have picked up.ldquoObviously we have genetic tendencies and some people are more prone to certain things than others, butwe pick up hundreds of habits in our le time then it shouldnrsquot be dficult to pick up new, good ones.ldquoIf we mentally reframe things into the positive, it can help, for example,we say lsquoI will eat more healthily or more thoughtfullyrsquo rather than lsquoIrsquom going to stop eating junk food and sweetsrsquo.ldquoIt also helps people to get their goals sounding more achievable and realistic.ldquoMost people nowadays have had the same resolutions year in year out, its usually about diet and exercise and enjoying le. I think how you frame it mentally is a big key to success.Martine explained that thinking about his own resolutions in a dferent way helped him to achieve a goal he set almost two decades ago.He said: ldquoI gave up drinking, more or less entirely. I didnrsquot have a problem or anything, other than being Scottish, I just thought I wanted to stop so I gave up in  and I found it was easy.ldquoThe way I managed it was to think about what I wanted to do, rather than what I donrsquot want to do.ldquoI knew I wanted to wake up in the morning feeling fresh and alert, and I knew that on a Sunday morning with a hangover that would be the opposite. The way I framed it was in terms of waking up feeling good, and I knew that not having alcohol in my system would help that process.Despite many peoplersquos resolutions staying the same over the past few decades, the way people think about them has moved towards a more negative mindset, according to Martin. It mirrors scientic findings which have shown people have a negative brain bias, and negative thoughts are more easily settled on than positive ones.According to American researcher Dr John Cacioppo, Ph.D, the brain reacts more strongly to negative stimuli, which is thought to be an evolutionary technique to help keep people out of harms way and protect them. Dr Cacioppo suggested the only way to counteract the negative bias is to have frequent, small positive experiences that will help sht the imbalance.Martin said small changes may not only help achieve a more positive outlook on le but could be another way to smash new yearrsquos resolution goals and change them in to lelong habits.The slow and steady approach is particular helpful, he said, when it comes to health-related goals as it gives the body time to adjust.According not a iety of reports. Around % of peoplersquos bew yearsrsquo resolutions are health-related, whileSchemes like Dry January, where people are encouraged to give up all alcohol for a month, or Veganuary, where people eat vegan meals in January, donrsquot help people to change their lestyle or habits in the long term, said Martin.He said: ldquoIf you try and make new yearrsquos resolutions practical and achievable, in small steps it should help you to stick to them, but I know that tends to go against the grain.ldquoWe are seeing more and more things like Veganuary and Dry January that encourage you to do something that you may not be used to, straight away.ldquoItrsquos betteryou just say lsquoIrsquom going to do this for the next few weeks.rsquo And start small. It could be something as small as adding a spoonful of salad to whatever you are eating, to get more nutrition that way.ldquoYou can then start to build that up gradually. Itrsquos better than making these sweeping changes.ldquoWhat you want to achieve is a lelong habit, in most cases. The way people live should be an ongoing continuous thing so they donrsquot have to stop and start, make a new resolution and then lapse.ldquoYou are trying to make a smooth adjustment from one way of living, so itrsquos better to see it as a long sweeping turn of a road.ldquoYou need to ease your way round and not make instant bending changes. Take little steps, keep it moving and I tend to find thatrsquos a much easier route.Along with slow, steady changes and positive thinking, not being too harsh on yourselfyou fail is another vital step to success.ldquoSelf compassion is so important. Martin said.ldquoThat is a really key principal of mindfulness but it is also importantpeople want to achieve their goalsldquoDonrsquot beat yourself up. If you are going on a diet, and you see a caramel wafer and you eat It, donrsquot think lsquooh no Irsquove ruined the diet and eat another  caramel wafers to compensate.ldquoThis happens often, but what people should really be trying to do is be kind to themselves.ldquoEverybody lapses and makes judgement errors and things like that."

title: former-snp-mp-to-appear-at-hearing-over-trust-fund
story: A five-day hearing opens tomorrow in Perth, led by the Law Society, against her and her then-partner Niall Mickel in the defunct firm Hamilton Burns. A Law Society solicitor, the fiscal, will present the case against her and Mickel.If the case of professional misconduct is proved, Ahmed-Sheikh and Mickel could be fined and even struck off as solicitors.Ahmed-Sheikh resigned as a director of Hamilton Burns when she was elected an MP in May . She has not practised law since then or since the company went bust in , owing, among other debts, pound, in tax.She was defeated in her seat in Ochil and South Perthshire in the  General Election and is now a partner with former SNP leader Salmond in Slainte Media, the company which produces Salmondrsquos weekly TV show for the Russian broadcaster RT. In one of the latest submissions to Companies House, Ahmed-Sheikh has changed her nationality from British to Scottish.In May , the Law Society launched an investigation into the handling of the trust fund by Hamilton Burns.Under the complaints procedure an investigation is first held andit is believed there is a case to answer it is then referred to the shyScottish Solicitorsrsquo Discipline Tribunal, which deals with serious disciplinary matters. The fact that the investigation has led to tomorrowrsquos hearing means that the Law Society believes there is a prima facie case against her and Mickel.The Law Society refused to comment ahead of the tribunal hearingAhmed-Sheikh did not respond to requests for comment. It is believed she will be represented in the procedure by the Edinburgh law firm Kennedys Law and is vigorously contesting the allegations against her.After the demise of Hamilton Burns, Mickel was understood to have been living and working as a ski instructor in Switzerland.
